Maani, my biggest problem with Schumer, besides his brazen hypocrisy and sense of privilege and entitlement to carry a gun, is his cozy relationship with New York's financial elite.  I know it's the biggest industry in New York by far, but surely even middle class New Yorkers would agree that finance is one industry badly in need of far stricter regulation. I'm no lawyer or expert on the Constitution, but I have read it and the Second Amendment, as I recall, states that "as part of a well-regulated militia, the right of the people to keep and bear arms shall not be abridged."   Actually, I learned that from Meathead on All in the Family, but I agree completely with him that not any and everybody who wants to carry a firearm has the right, and it's certainly not part of a well-regulated militia.

Yes, but what are you saying? We should abort all children? I'm hoping that is not what you intended. I totally support birth control, having fewer children, and abortion rights, but I'd like our world population to decline through increased education and female empowerment. Hopefully you agree.

It's possible that birth rates are declining and our population as a whole will fall world wide.  Read this on Slate:  "About That Overpopulation Problem:  Research suggests we may actually face a declining world population in the coming years," by Jeff Wise on January 9th of 2013.

No. "Pro-choice" does not equal only one choice, in fact that's the complete opposite of what it means.

Are you actually suggesting that every pregnancy should be terminated, regardless of what the woman wants? I don't think you know what that phrase means.

Women need to do what's right for the planet - not what's right for their emotions. There's a more important mother involved in these decisions - Mother Earth, and she is groaning under the weight of so many children. Those of us who call ourselves pro-choice know there's really only one choice that's morally defensible.

Oh, come on Moira. I understand the desire to identify with the truly downtrodden, but your facile use of "white male" here to divide everyone else into a "have not" class is silly. Didn't you read the article? I grew up in what is called by outsiders "Appalachia", surrounded by dirt poor families, most of whom, males and females alike, were white. A lot of them, male and female, are still dirt poor, and they have a lot of company now. Or do you think every "white boy" is a CEO?

The middle and upper classes in the US consisted then and consist now mostly of white people, about half of which are female. And "heterosexual white" females are never racist or sexist, just the white males? On what planet?

Mr/Ms Measures: Heterosexual, white baby boomer (birth class of 1952) here and I'd like to know at what end of the stick I'm coming up short? And, Moira, yes, we've all "set the foundation for racism, sexism and homophobia - ignorance, arrogance and hatred."

We're also responsible for ring around the collar, that dog poo into which I stepped in 1983, Bill Buckner's error (ok...maybe you got me here) and Manti Te'o. Damn!!!
By what possible measure are heterosexual, white, male baby boomers getting the short end of the stick?

And what group, ironically, though at the forefront of helping to make these gains take place, has come up at the short end of the stick, and is now suffering the most?! Heterosexual, white, male baby boomers! Who'da thunk it?! Sort of becoming, though still very much alive, like dead white European classical music composers, of the Romantic period!!!

Actually, in-law problems are sometimes even MORE prominent in arranged marriages.  One, because the woman generally moves in with her in-laws, so that friction is always ever-present (though more and more couples are living on their own these days)--this is the big theme of almost all Indian soap operas.  Secondly, even when the couple lives independently, since the parents have always had such a big role in their children's lives up to that point, the interference continues even after the marriage to a larger extent than would be tolerated in mainstream American society.

Yes, it's human nature to always want more, regardless of how much one already has; but it's been the job of governments to level the playing field, reclaim excessive profits via the government. If our government refuses, we fail; and eventually the country will fail. Very serious stuff. Thanks, Dr. Stiglitz.

You know, Pam, I don't think it is human nature to always want more. I think endless greed is a learned condition. Sure, people want enough for a good life, but I don't know anybody who's willing to engage is legal thievery to get a Gulfstream, a 20K sf house, a dress that costs $10,000, etc.

But, then, I don't live around people whose interior landscape is impoverished. I live around people who know who they are, know what they want, appreciate what they have (they're middle class and fairly well educated, so they're privileged and they know it), and are, by and large, content.

Also, they're mostly older. I'm 63 and not rich, but not poor either. Suits me right down to the ground. What I want more of is rich experiences and continued ood health. Not zillions of dollars.

I think many of us, especially as we get older, if we've been fortunate enough to get an education, have a stable home and emotional life, and a decent but not luxurious standard of living, realize that getting more stuff isn't a recipe for happiness. Human nature's pliable. The folks I've known in life who were the greediest were, more often than not, the least happy. For many of us, enough really is enough when it comes to material wealth.

Inequality is a pervasive problem of mankind.

A small percentage of people in most countries live with the vast majority of the wealth. People are literally starving so that the rich can have more. That is the case in this country, and the assumption is made that we need to somehow maintain the status quo and still have an economic recovery. The Republicans say that the only way to keep giving the rich more is to take more from the rest of the people - and they say that this is the only way.

Come on . . .
Who really thinks this makes sense?
So why is Europe in such a mess?  Did every European country pass the Community Reinvestment Act?

Are you for real? He's a self absorbed narcissist who's done nothing to rebuild the private sector, leaving tens of millions unemployed, investors fearful of investment while he plays golf and attends parties in Martha's Vineyard.   His class warfare rhetoric does nothing but deflect attention from his own failures while dividing the productive classes from the unproductive. Tell me how Obama's claims that doctors only want to rip off medicare, bankers all want to steal our money, and millionaires are all leeches that made their money by oppression and theft could motivate any tax PAYER to invest money or hire more people?   Does Obama really believe that stealing from people who work while telling them they're thieves helps the country???

Perhaps we should stop all contributions by unions, nonprofits, pacs, and corporations.  We should also stop lobbyists, congressional aids, and federal agency bureaucrats from writing the legislation or bills our elected officials vote on.  Most of the time, like with Obamacare, they have no idea what they are voting for other than the pork-belly riders they attach to the bill.

"their wealth and the influence it gives them in a money-driven political system remain."

The outsize influence of wealth in our political system is the next big challenge. That must change before more can be done, or what has been done be safe.

At the end of the day everything that everyone thinks they know about God or a lack of God comes down to belief! Until someone can explain what existed prior to the beginning of this Universe God is as likely as any other explanation. Even if an explanation does exist and we can understand it God still can exist.

There are a number of extra dimensions required by the latest theories in Physics, we know nothing about most of them. There are billions of planets most of which we have never seen. To state that there was, is, and will never be a God is the ultimate act of unsupported belief.

Socrates, I respectfully disagree. Science cannot give a fully satisfying answer to questions like, "Why an I here", or, "Why do I exist?".

No matter how much science, fact and reason occupy a culture, science will not be able to fully explain humanity, warts and all.

Religion fills that gap for enough people to render science incomplete.
As long as binary thinking and power hunger exist, we will have religion. Not sure if those human traits will ever evolve on outta here...

" I wager, in fact, that many professed Christians are not at all sure about the truth of these doctrines —and other believers have similar doubts. They are, quite properly, religious agnostics."

That's the truest part of your essay, Professor Gutting.

I would wager that most people are in fact agnostic, but simply lack the public bravery, the individual backbone or the intellectual curiosity to think it through and admit it to themselves and others.

Remember, the vast majority of religious people had religion boiled into their brain as intellectually defenseless children under the undue influence of parents, grandparents and extended family. The case for the legitimacy of religion is heavily tainted as it most closely resembles cultism more than realism.

Agnostics and atheists, which are growing in the modern, industrialized world, tend to emigrate from the religious world toward agnosticism and atheism, but the converse of that almost never happens.

Religion will slowly fade away over time as modernity, science, fact and reason will appropriately steamroll religion into intellectual oblivion.

Religion doesn't pass the logic test; it is merely a fatally flawed 'fear-of-death' placebo pill and the world's most popular psychological disorder.
And he will go down in history as one of the greatest presidents of the U.S..
Is a victory for something which was wrong to start out with still a victory?

On the one hand, you have those who believe that, had Obama only been nicer to or more persuasive with Republicans, he could have gotten what he wanted. On the other hand, there are those who believe that, had Obama just "stood his ground", he would have carried the day on single payer, taxes, spending and a host of other issues during his first term.

The truth is that Republicans could not be reasoned with - no way, no how. No amount of cajoling could move them off their determined, premeditated obstruction. And Obama could not simply throw down the gauntlet, either, because too many Senators and Congressmen in his own party were weak-kneed when confronted with right wing demagoguery. We're seeing this even now with attempts to reform the filibuster. Democrats have the votes numerically but are backing down.

Obama has been swimming against the current for 4 years. Every victory has been hard fought and diminished to some degree in order to move forward. Finally, after a convincing re-election, Obama now has momentum and real public support. Republicans have overplayed their hand, the economy is improving and Obama is seizing the day. That doesn't mean that there won't be compromise, but Obama will get most of what he wants from here on out.

Hiding from the world is proof enough that the North Korean and Iranian regimes cannot withstand scrutiny even from their own people -- less they should find out that the regimes have fully succeeded in stifling economic development.
Yet North Korea and Iran could just as easily have excelled economically as well as technologically -- for the greater good of their citizens.
As things stand now, Iran has abandoned all paths to the country's Persian greatness, and daily North Korea has to face the glaring economic disparities with its sister state.
Exactly how long will it take for these regimes to realize that in today's world a country's might is measured in economic terms?
Indeed, even if the North Korean and Iranian regimes on their own somehow managed to amass Russia's military might, neither would be further ahead economically.
So what's the point in trying?

The oil dependency is solved by fracking (at least for the next 50 years). After that renewable sources will take over.  Obama care is a totally worthless kluge. Why could be not just have a simple clean universal insurance scheme? Something like Switzerland. So sad.  Regulation is not the answer. The answer is simply to make sure the bankers always have plenty of their own skin in the game. The government should never "insure" a private business against losses. We forgot that rule and that is what caused the sub-prime crisis.  Our real problem is that we need a better tax system. I am convinced that this is the real cause of our slow growth economy. The fact that people have to keep records and file income tax returns is nonsense. All taxes should be collected by payroll deduction similar to the medicare tax. Then, to make the system progressive,  the government should simply rebate some of the money to low income workers.  We should also withhold taxes from interest and dividend checks and from all the various sorts of executive compensation (i.e. perks and options and stock). Capital gains should be tax free. Corporations should not be taxed according to the total amount they pay their executive officers and their board members.

Obama's fantasy dream of a healthier nation that does in fact parasitize its own working and middle class and the poor and the business owners.

One day people will wake up and realize the dream of hope and change was or is a nightmare and the country will get back on the path to restoring our greatness. Right now where we are headed economically, socially, and politically looks like a deep dark hole we are trying to get out of by shoveling more dirt out of it.

FDR and Obama both inherited nations with remarkably similar levels of inequality. But even FDR didn't have to deal with this organized and vicious an opposition to his progressive policies.

I don't agree with everything President Obama does. But I believe in his vision of a healthier nation that does not parasitize its own working and middle class.

Progressives need to be ever active, but must forgive the President if he sometimes seems to stray while navigating the minefield his opponents have created. The nation is on the right path.

You seem to be arguing that Noda's move to purchase the islands was an act of aggression. As you know, by doing so, he prevented a highly nationalistic politician from further increasing tensions. China has used this as an excuse to point the finger at Japan, but it was disingenuous as the ccp understands why Noda did this (to maintain the status quo).

China is not a new bully, in that it has been bullying its own people for decades--starving, murdering, labor camps, and so on. Of course, conditions have improved, but bullying does continue.

It doesn't seem that there was any dispute until China learned that there were potential oil reserves in the waters surrounding the islands in the late sixties. If you were in charge of a country and were administering a set of islands for 70 or so years, and another country learned there might be oil around the islands and starting making claims, would you find it reasonable to validate their claims? Even if the islands are not Jpns, wouldn't it be more accurate to say they belong to Taiwan. Would PRC accept this?
Workers responsible for profits?  Corporations equally responsible to all?  A  nice slice of Marx; sounds GREAT to me, but it sets Wall Street's hair on fire.

The reason that there is such a disparity to start with is that within the last few decades, the top 1% has been able to divert greatly increased corporate profits into their own pockets instead of sharing with the workers who are responsible for the profits in the first place. Their income has risen to the tune of almost 300% while the bottom half has remained stagnant.

This is the source of the problem, and the solution is to make sure that workers get paid. How to do that? How about strengthening unions so that power is shared rather than solely in the hands of management? How about changing corporate tax law so that all executive remuneration above a multiple of the lowest paid worker is ineligible to be deducted as an expense for income tax purposes. How about raising the minimum wage at the same time to where it would be if it were adjusted for inflation? How about killing this idea that the sole purpose of a corporation is to pay stockholders, and instead make corporations equally responsible to their workers and to their customers as well?

It happened in stages. So many people that are educated and intelligent have no expectation of their lives improving. Their children face the prospect of downward mobility. So many have lost their homes. their jobs , their 401Ks and expectation of a comfortable retirement. What happened to their rights? They were whittled away in the past decade a little at a time. Right under our noses, even our constitutional rights have been lessened during past few presidential terms.

It used to be as well that the corporation was a safe haven for the American family. Now, a worker feels fortunate not to be thrown out into the street by the corporation just as his son/daughter is going off to college. In a movement to save the inefficient corporation, management seeks to break it up, layoff its workers and offshore their jobs. The corporate structure has become a noose around the neck of the middle class with its short term outlook and protracted goals. Attention to the bottom line snipping away at the American Dream. Many from their ranks have lost their way of life and sense of purpose.

What will become of Medicare, Medicaid, unemployment insurance and Social Security and our school systems?
They are targets of the Republican right. These benefits are the only systems that separate the middle class from the poor and indigent. As politicians carve away at these programs, they are bargaining away the future of the middle class in the US and the future of our country.

To Ms. Albright, Gen. Powell might have responded "Si vis pacem, para bellum", if you wish for peace, prepare for war. It's been a guiding principle since at least the Roman empire.
As for "the notion that experience of war imparts a special wisdom is one of our enduring fallacies.", and "among the reasons to vote yes, the fact that Hagel has tasted combat should be regarded with skepticism.", let's take yet another look at some ancient wisdom. Karl Marlantes, at the beginning of "What It's Like to Go to War", quotes Thucydides, who in turn quotes a Spartan General: "A nation that makes a great distinction between it's scholars and it's warriors will have it's thinking done by cowards and it's fighting done by fools". Dick Cheney comes to mind.
Marlantes and dozens of others have gone to great lengths to document the brutality and despair as well as the excitement and transcendence of being in combat. Sorry to say, sometimes it can be sublime. They all describe in great detail the physical aspects including the simultaneous occurrence of multiple bodily functions you wouldn't think could coexist. Marlantes takes it quite a bit further into the realm of the mental and spiritual in his book.
The bottom line for everyone though, is it changes you. Once experienced, you've crossed a line. Once crossed, we all deal with it differently, but if you haven't crossed it, it's hard to see over it with clarity. Judging anyone through that haze, or fog of war, is blind justice.

Secretary Albright's question was profound, in two ways.

First, genocide was taking place in Europe, and we and our NATO allies had been trying to ignore it. We can't fix every problem on earth, but it's a good thing that we finally intervened in that one.

Second, we were, and still are, spending vast sums of money on the military. Sec. Albright's question made us stop, for a moment at least, and ask ourselves why.

Senator Hagel may not be the ideal Secretary of Defense in every way. But if he can do anything to start bringing our stratospheric military spending back down to earth, and if he is inclined to try, we should support him, at least in that.

The point is that we spend hundreds of billions on a military, then have to pay trillions more for that military to fight. Sort of like having a salaried cleaning staff on hand that gets paid even more to do the cleaning.

"But the notion that experience of war imparts a special wisdom is one of our enduring fallacies."

No. It is not a fallacy. He could never think what Madeline Albright said to Colin Powell, "What's the point of having this superb military that you're always talking about if we can't use it?" That is a vital starting point for the guy in charge of it all.

I think you should give us your definition of freedom before saying the right hates freedom more than the left.  Personally I think it is the left who wants to restrict freedom of speech, freedom of religion, freedom of type of gun ownership, and imposes regulations which impede business growth and development.  There are a few on the right who want to impose restrictions on what they consider moral choices or they don't want to pay for peoples moral choices.  On balance the left is more guilty of suppression of freedom than the right.
What did Obama have to do with takeover of the state legislatures?  The gerrymandering we see today would have occurred regardless of him, no?

Yeah, very much too bad.  He had a huge opening the first six months, even a year, and wasted it all over tea & crumpets with people who hated him then and apparently like him no better now.  It seemed to me then (and still) that his desire to join the status quo was greater than his desire to change it.

The simple truth is that President Obama did not concentrate on jobs, jobs, jobs from day one. He did not dedicate himself to driving a stake through the heart of the Republican Party (the way the Republican Party dedicated itself to destroying him). He was naive, ill-prepared and ineffective. The result was a disastrous 2010 midterm election, takeovers of legislatures, gerrymandering and voter suppression that will require a decade (at least) before we can expect any real progressive legislation. Too bad we didn't have a politically savvy President who would lead us into battle against right-wing forces who hate us for our freedoms.

Your suggestion would inevitably lead to even worse inequality.  Less power for government means more for wealthy business interests.  And what do they want?  High profits and low taxes for themselves, low wages for everyone else.  In other words, more inequality.

The "understanding" part of the discussion is not a little bit murky. It seems to refer to an esthetic or psychological experience. Yes, there are aspects of the religious experience that everyone can identify with--the need for atonement; a quest for absolutes; a desire to find personal meaning within a purposeful, larger framework; a need for some ultimate caring in the universe. But within religion, all these experiences seem short-circuited by the knowledge dimension. Answers are given,  not just in creeds but in devotion to religious mystery. For the unbeliever, there is never a clear answer. To my mind, the most satisfying psychological and esthetic experiences are independent of this "knowledge" or belief base, and they entertain doubt and ambiguity.
